awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: EAGER: Generation of High Resolution Surface Melting Maps over Antarctica Using Regional Climate Models, Remote Sensing and Machine Learning
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2).

Climate change is promoting increased melting in Greenland and Antarctica, contributing to the global sea level rise. Understanding what drives the increase and the amount of meltwater from the ice sheets is paramount to improve our skills to project future sea level rise and associated consequences. Melting in Antarctica mostly occurs along ice shelves (tongues of ice floating in the water). They do not contribute directly to sea level when they melt but their disappearance allows the glaciers at the top to flow faster towards the ocean, increasing the contribution of Antarctica to sea level rise. Satellite data can only offer a partial view of what is happening, either because of limited coverage or because of the presence of clouds, which often obstruct the view in this part of the world. Models, on the other hand, can provide estimates but the spatial detail they can provide is still limited by many factors. This project will use artificial intelligence to overcome these problems and to merge satellite data and model outputs to generate daily maps of surface melting with unprecedented detail. These techniques are similar to those used in cell phones to sharpen images or to create landscapes that look “real” but are only existing in the “computer world,” but they have never been applied to melting in Antarctica for improving estimates of sea level rise. 

Meltwater in Antarctica has been shown to impact ice shelf stability through the fracturing and flexural processes. Image scarcity has often forced the community to use general climate and regional climate models to explore hydrological features. Notwithstanding models having been considerably refined over the past years, they still require improvements in capturing the processes driving the energy balance and, most importantly, the feedback among the drivers and the energy balance terms that drive the hydrological processes. Moreover, spatial resolution is still too coarse to properly capture hydrological processes, especially over ice shelves. Machine learning (ML) tools can help in this regard, especially when it is computationally infeasible to run physics-based models at desired resolutions in space and time, like in the case of ice shelf surface hydrology. This project will train Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) with the outputs of a regional climate model and remote sensing data to generate unprecedented, high-resolution (100 m) maps of surface melting. Beside improving the spatial resolution, and hence providing a long-needed and crucial dataset to the polar community, the tool here proposed will be able to provide satellite-like maps on a daily basis, hence addressing also those issues related to the lack of spatial coverage.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Outcomes Report 

Meltwater on top of Antarctic ice shelves can indicate ice shelf collapse and is a key variable for studying the ice sheet mass balance. Despite its importance, observations of surface meltwater only exist at low spatio-temporal resolutions with observational gaps, which hinders advances in modeling the collapse of ice shelves. Existing downscaling techniques to create high-resolution maps are either too low-resolution or overly dependent on single inputs, such as digital elevation maps. This project evaluated if generative vision models can improve the downscaling of surface meltwater.

 

Specifically, we:

  • have assembled a robust benchmark dataset to determine the best method for downscaling daily high-resolution (100m) surface meltwater,

  • concurrently, created a benchmark for data-driven downscaling useful beyond the Cryosphere,

  • developed a generative vision model that downscales surface meltwater maps,

  • organized two workshops in ML and cryo with over 300 total participants

  • will release the manuscript and dataset in Summer 2024

 

Fig.1, We have assembled a robust benchmark dataset to determine the best method for data-driven downscaling of surface meltwater.

Dataset: 

To create robust benchmark for downscaling methods that is accessible to the machine learning community, we have first formulated a the task as a generative vision problem: A model aims to find the best prediction of surface meltwater at 100m resolution from the low-resolution inputs from passive microwave satellite observations, a regional climate model, a static digital elevation model, and other information. For the generative vision problem visualized in Fig. 1, we have the inputs available on a daily basis, but the ground-truth only available every 2-7 days. Thus, with a random train/val/test split in time, the winning model can robustly claim to create a product of daily high-resolution surface meltwater over the Helheim Glacier for 2017-2022. 

 

For this dataset, we have created ground-truth maps of surface meltwater at 100m and 2-7 days resolution from Sentinel-1A and B Synthetic Aperture Radar observations. We generated daily outputs from a regional climate model, MARv3.14, at 5km which predicts surface meltwater and auxiliary information such as winds. We added daily 3km passive microwave (PMW) satellite observations from NASA Measures, 500m visual MODIS observations, and a static 100m digital elevation map (DEM). 

 

Metrics: 

A good benchmark dataset contains a set of evaluation metrics that are useful for cryospheric scientists to identify the best models. We noticed that the easy-to-interpret metrics (e.g., MSE) were not sensitive enough for downscaling meltwater. Thus, we wrote the code for a structural similarity index metric (SSIM) on masked images which helped us identify the best models. 

 

Fig. 2a. Our first baseline model, interpolate-mar, is the optimal spatial interpolation of the low-resolution predictions from the regional climate model, MARv3.14. 

 

Fig. 2b. Our second baseline model, time-interpolate-sar, is temporal interpolation of the high-resolution surface meltwater observations in the training set, similar to a climatological mean.

 

 

Models:

We have implemented four models on our benchmark dataset to evaluate the pros and cons of each method. First, we found the optimal spatial interpolation of the MAR model outputs (MAR interpolate) in Fig. 2a. Second in Fig. 2b, we calculated a running mean of the SAR-derived high-resolution surface meltwater observations from the training set, similar to predicting the climatological mean. 

 

We compare these two baseline models with a UNet, which is a competitive baseline architecture from generative vision modeling, specifically image-to-image translation. The UNet uses MAR, PMW, DEM, and the predictions of the time-interpolate-sar model as inputs. We had first designed a UNet that only uses MAR, PMW, and DEM as input, because it could theoretically be used as a hindcast to generate high-resolution meltwater predictions for 2000-2017, but found that the UNet with time-interpolate-sar inputs has significantly better predictions. Finally, we include the DeepLabv3+ model which is a slightly advanced UNet.

 

Results:

 

We find that the UNet creates the highest quality downscaling product as exemplified by the Figures 3a, b. In a quantitative comparison in Fig. 4, we find that the interpolate-mar model underpredicts melting in the late Summer. The UNet is able to correct for these biases and Tab. 1 confirms that it has the best scores across the validation set. 

 

Fig 3a. Predictions of surface meltwater on 2018/06/30.

Fig 3b. Errors in predictions of surface meltwater on 2018/06/30.

 

Fig. 4, Comparison of downscaling methods on the validation dataset.

 

Tab. 1, Validation scores of each model.

 

Discussion:

 

The UNet lead our benchmark indicating the promise of deep learning-based methods for generating daily high-resolution (100m) surface meltwater products and downscaling beyond the cryospheric sciences. The UNet can fail, e.g., due to overrelying on the time-interpolate-sar inputs, which could be addressed by improvements in the model architecture, regularization, or including other inputs. Follow-up studies that investigate the feature importance, models for hind- and forecasts, or extrapolations to the Antarctic would be very interesting.
